instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
Tested with good display, also no backlight. Unit chimes and Image is visible with flashlight. No liquid damage that I can tell.
Having difficulty narrowing down the problem.

[B]Here's what I got so far:[/B]
<CAPACITOR>C9799</CAPACITOR> - 12.52V
<CAPACITOR>C9797</CAPACITOR> - 12.52V
<CAPACITOR>C9796</CAPACITOR> - 12.52V
L9701 - 12.55V
<RESISTOR>R0910</RESISTOR> - 12.5V
<CHIP>U9701</CHIP> - 3.1V pin 3 // 007.0mV pin 6
<CAPACITOR>C9712</CAPACITOR>/13 - 12.55V
<TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> - 4.35V pin 3 // 12.55V all other pins
L9080 - 1.2V all pins // all traces good
F9700 - 12.5V both sides
<CAPACITOR>C9711</CAPACITOR> - 3.3V pin 1
J9000 - 3.3V pins 4, 6, 7 // 12.6V pins 21, 22 (connector and all pins look good)
<RESISTOR>R9715</RESISTOR> - 3.1V pin 2
<RESISTOR>R5071</RESISTOR> - 3.4V both pins

There are a few slightly discolored probe points in the <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> area but no signs of liquid exposure or corrosion anywhere.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
PRAM Reset was done, issue persists.
<SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> (measured on <CAPACITOR>C9704</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR>) = 3.3V

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message: Bad <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> or a corroded feedback trace.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message: Removed <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> and checked all traces, everything OK there. Ordered replacement <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> and will see where that takes me.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
Finally got around to continuing work on this machine. <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> was replaced and now I get no power, no chime, just a quarter fan spin.
When I listen close there is a buzzing sound coming from the fan when I press the power button.
Magsafe light is ok, green at first then red because battery is empty.
When battery is disconnected, magsafe shows green with a constant quick flicker about 2-3 times per second.

Where do I go from here?

Could the <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> be oriented wrong? I assumed the dot on the new chip corresponds with the dot on the old chip.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message: Post picture of <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> for us to check or remove it see if the board fires up.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
No Title

Will remove it tomorrow to check for power, didn’t think of that..

chip was ordered from mailin.repair, didn’t come from a donor board.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message: I'm pretty sure I see balls squishing out. Did you touch it when reflowing? Remove it and see if board works again.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
A bit of solder did pop out the side. 
Chip came with balls on it so I wicked the pads (I already put some solder on), put some flux, flowed in the new chip. 

Let me guess, I’m not supposed to push it down on the board? (Because I did)

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message: Pushing it down is a sure way to short all the balls together. Pull it off and put another chip, do not touch it while reflowing.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
No Title

Lesson learned, don't push <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> to the board :)
Removed, wicked, placed another one (properly) and we got a happy Mac with power and backlight.
Thanks for all the help!
